title: WPP shares jump 6% as ad giant returns to growth for first time in a year
text:
After a challenging year FTSE 100 listed advertising giant WPP has returned to quarterly sales growth, sending its shares more than 6 per cent higher.

The group, which started life in 1985 as a maker of wire shopping baskets, revealed organic growth of 0.7 per cent in the past three months as a strong performance in Europe and offset decay in the US.

While the City had predicted another quarter of decline, comparable revenues rose by 1.9 per cent to £3.29billion during the period.

Relieved investors snapped up shares, taking WPP stock to £9.76 in morning trading on Friday

WPP put the progress partly down to major client wins such as new agreements to work with eBay and chocolate giant Mondelez.

Relieved investors snapped up shares, taking WPP stock 6 per cent higher to £9.74 towards market close on Friday.

That's despite the company's insistence that it is still likely to post a full-year sales fall of between 1.5 per cent and 2 per cent.

Mark Read (above) took the reins at WPP last year following the departure of former boss Sir Martin Sorrell

Mark Read, who took the reins last year amid the sudden departure of founder and former boss Sir Martin Sorrell, said the numbers were 'encouraging', reflecting his shift in strategy.

Read is eager to streamline the business and boost the balance sheet.

Shares have fallen by more than 90 per cent in the past two years.

The WPP lifer masterminded the disposal of 60 per cent of its Kantar research division - a move that gained shareholder approval earlier this week.

'WPP's performance in the third quarter is another important step in the strategy we outlined in December 2018 to return the company to sustainable growth in line with our peers in 2021,' Read said.

'Our growth in quarter three is encouraging but we are focused on delivering these longer-term goals and know there will be twists and turns along the way.'

Russ Mould from AJ Bell said that WPP's turnaround appears to be 'gaining some traction' - impressive given the 'weak performance at some of its global peers of late'.

According to Begbies Traynor, the number of media companies in significant distress has increased by 45 per cent since the 2016 referendum as more companies take marketing in-house.

Mould said: 'Read had always signalled 2019 would be a year of consolidation and the progress he has made means he has credit in the bank with investors.

'However, the company will likely face a higher bar in 2020.'
